text:
Why ignoring stress is dangerous to health
02 Nov 2019, 10:00 by LIFE HACKER AND PUBLISHING HOUSE ‚ÄúMANN, IVANOV AND FERBER‚Äù
Excerpt from the book ‚ÄúBurnout. A New Approach to Relieving Stress ‚Äùabout how the habit of running away from problems can result in chronic overstrain.
Complete the cycle
‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to sell drugs, just to leave this job‚Äù - so Julia, a friend of Amelia, answered the question ‚ÄúHow are you?‚Äù It was the last Saturday before the start of the school year. Julia was just joking. However, the situation was nowhere more serious. She works as a teacher in high school. Her burnout has reached a critical point. The thought of the beginning of the next quarter makes the poor man reach for a bottle of wine at two in the afternoon.
Who will like that the teacher of his child is overwhelmed with cynicism and drinks his bitter life with alcohol? But there are many. Burnout devastates, smothers apathy, and most importantly, the teacher becomes callous - there are more such cases than you might think.
- Somehow I came across a note about a teacher who appeared at school on the first school day so drunk that he forgot his pants. And I said to myself: ‚ÄúLord is the witness, this is your future,‚Äù Julia admitted, having drained the first glass.
‚ÄúDespair is an overwhelming alarm,‚Äù Amelia answered, recalling her own teaching experience. ‚ÄúAnd anxiety builds up because of the stress that builds up day after day and never ends.‚Äù
- Gold words! - announced Julia, topping herself up with wine.
‚ÄúThe problem with the school is that you will never get rid of the causes of your stress,‚Äù Amelia continued. ‚ÄúAnd I'm not talking about children.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù Julia said. - In children, on the contrary, the whole point. But the administration, reports and pieces of paper are terribly annoying. ‚ÄúAnd you will never get rid of them.‚Äù But you can do something with stress itself. Complete the stress response cycle.
- I totally agree! Julia nodded. - Wait, what kind of cycle?
In this chapter, we will answer Julia's question. The answer at the same time is the basic idea of the whole book. "Recycling" stress and getting rid of its causes are completely separate processes. To stress does not accumulate, you must go all the way.
Stress
To begin with, we will learn to separate these two things.
There are stressors. They can be anything: everything that you see, hear, touch, smell or even imagine in your mind is a threat. Stressors are external: work, money, family, time, social norms and expectations, experience of discrimination, and so on. And there are internal ones. They are more difficult to describe, and they are much finer. Self-criticism, rejection of one‚Äôs appearance, difficulties with self-determination, negative memories, fear of the future - to varying degrees, all these factors can be determined by your body as a potential threat.
Stress is a nervous and physiological reaction of an organism in a situation when you are faced with one of the above dangers.
This mechanism developed in the course of evolution in order to cope with the sudden attack of a lion or, say, a hippopotamus. As soon as the brain fixes an aggressive animal, an automatic ‚Äústress response‚Äù starts in us - a chain of changes throughout the body that adapts the body to increased stress. It will be hot now! Adrenaline fills the muscles with extra blood, glucocorticoids keep them in good shape, and endorphins help to ignore all this discomfort. Your heart goes to a fast rhythm, blood shocks in the arteries become more powerful, which increases blood pressure in the vessels, and you have to breathe often (often monitoring the cardiovascular system is a favorite way for scientists to measure stress levels). Muscles become tense, sensitivity to pain is reduced, attention is sharpened, but it becomes tunnel - you are focused on the current moment and on what is happening right under your nose. All senses work to the fullest, and only information directly related to the stressor is snatched from the depths of memory. To maximize your survival, the body temporarily ‚Äúextinguishes‚Äù the activity of other organs: digestion slows down, the immune system indicators change (analysis of immune activity is the second favorite way for scientists to fix stress). Cell growth and restoration will wait, reproductive function is also irrelevant. Your whole body and psyche change in response to what you perceive as a threat.
And here is the lion! Stress reaction floods you to the ears. What are your next steps?
To run!
You see, this whole complex, multi-stage reaction has a single goal - to deliver the maximum amount of oxygen and energy to your muscles to give you the opportunity to avoid meeting the enemy. The remaining processes are temporarily inhibited. As Robert Sapolsky put it: ‚ÄúIn our vertebrates, the stress response is based on a simple fact: a crazy race awaits your muscles.‚Äù
In general, you ran.
What's next?
Two options. Either the lion eats you (or the hippopotamus tramples - it does not matter, then you do not care), or you are saved! You reach your village, the lion is on the heels, but you are struggling to call for help! People run out to kill a predator together, and you managed to survive. Victory! You rush to cuddle with your family and neighbors. Life is good, you are filled with gratitude. The sun shines twice as bright, and you gradually relax, realizing that it is safe to be in your body again. Then you and your fellow villagers carve the carcass, fry a large piece on the fire and feast together. Take the rest, inedible parts of the lion away and bury with a special ritual. Returning home, holding hands with your fellow villagers, whom you love so much. Inhale deeply the native air and thank the lion for its sacrifice.
The stress response is over. Thanks to everybody, you're free.
You coped with the stressor, but what about the stress itself?
The human stress response was ideally tailored to the environment in which our species evolved. Actions to neutralize the ‚Äúlion‚Äù simultaneously discharged the stress response. And here you might think that the stress reaction cycle always ends by eliminating the stressor - the cause of stress.
But such an interpretation would be too simple.
Imagine that you are running away from a lion in a severe thunderstorm. Lightning flashes all around, and suddenly one of them hits a predator! You turn around and see his lifeless body. But do sudden peace and tranquility fill you? Oh no! You are at a loss, your heart is pounding wildly. Look around for other dangers. Your body still wants to break loose: to run or fight! Or hide in a cave and roar? The gods punished this toothy monster, but your body still does not feel safe. The stress response cycle must be completed. The mere disappearance of the threat is not enough. Most likely, you will run into the village and, panting, tell the villagers your horrible story. Everyone will groan with fear and jump with happiness with you. Praise heavenly deities for saving lightning!
And here is the modern version. Leo is ready to rush at you! Adrenaline, cortisol, glycogen - the whole cocktail works to its fullest. You grab a gun, broads! The lion is shot, you are saved.
Now what? The threat has disappeared, but your body is still under the avalanche of physiological reactions. You still have not performed actions that the body recognizes as a signal to relax. It is useless to say to yourself: "Calm down, everything is fine." Not even the sight of a shot lion will help. We need actions that symbolize security. Otherwise, you will remain with this ‚Äúcocktail‚Äù of hormones and neurotransmitters. Over time, it will stretch, but relaxation will not come. The digestive, immune, cardiovascular, musculoskeletal and reproductive systems will remain depressed if they do not receive a signal to return to full work.
And that's not all!
Imagine that your stressor is not a lion, but some idiot colleague. It does not threaten your life at all, but it is dirty about trifles. There is a meeting, he again inserts his stupid comment, and you - oh my God - pour adrenaline with cortisol and glycogen. However, you have to decorously sit with this idiot at the same table and be nice. Perform a socially approved role. Who will feel better if you jump across the table and scratch his arrogant little eyes? Your physiology craves the blood of the enemy. But instead, you have a calm, socially acceptable, highly constructive meeting with his boss. He agrees to support you. And if this moron begins to arise again, the senior manager will remind him of corporate ethics.
Our congratulations!
You coped with the stressor, but the stress itself has not yet gone. It impregnates the entire body until you perform magical relaxing actions.
Day after day passes ... But the ‚Äúhang up‚Äù command is still there and there is no.
Let's see what happens to one of the systems - cardiovascular. Chronically activated stress response leads to increased pressure. Your vessels are designed for a gentle flow of blood, and she - just imagine! - whips like from a garden hose. Naturally, they wear out faster, break, and the risk of heart disease increases.
Chronic stress seems harmless, but it causes life-threatening illnesses.
And remember that this overload occurs in every organ and every system of your body. Digestion. Immunity. Hormonal background. The human body is not designed to live in this state. If we get stuck in it, the stress response instead of saving our lives slowly kills us.
In Western post-industrial society, everything is turned upside down. In most cases, stress kills us faster than the stressor that caused it. And this will continue until you consciously complete the cycle of the launched stress reaction. While you deal with daily stressors, your body is trying to clear up daily stress. You must give the body resources to discharge. And this task is critically important for your well-being, along with sleep and food.
But first you need to figure out why we are not doing it right now.
Why are we stuck
A cycle can freeze halfway for a variety of reasons. Most often, we observe three:
1. Chronic stressor ‚Üí chronic stress. Sometimes our¬†the brain starts a stress reaction, you do what it asks for, but the situation itself does not change.
‚ÄúRun!‚Äù - the brain commands, when they threw you a frightening task: to speak to colleagues, write a giant report or go through a responsible interview.
Living in the XXI century, you begin to ‚Äúrun‚Äù as it is characteristic of our contemporaries. Arriving home in the evening, put Beyonc√©'s album and dance for half an hour selflessly.
‚ÄúWe ran away from a predator!‚Äù The brain proclaims. You catch your breath, smile from ear to ear. ‚ÄúWho is great? Well done! ‚ÄùAs a reward, the brain produces a whole list of biochemical substances that create a sense of serene happiness.
But the evil morning comes ... A frightening task awaits you in the same place.
‚ÄúRun!‚Äù The brain exclaims.
And the cycle begins anew.
We are stuck in a stress reaction because we endlessly return to a stressful situation.
This is not bad in itself. Harm begins where our ability to defuse tension ends. And this happens regularly, because ...
2. Social norms. Sometimes the brain activates a stress response, but you cannot carry out what it requires.
- Team run!
And he gives in to adrenaline.
- I can not! - you answer. - I'm sitting on the exam!
Or so:
- Let's give this impudence on the head!
And you feel a wave of glucocorticoids in the blood.
‚ÄúI can't give him a beat!‚Äù This is my client! - you lament.
You need to sit, smile politely, and conscientiously perform a training or work task. Meanwhile, your body is boiled in a cauldron of stress and expects you to begin to act.
And it‚Äôs even worse. Society may inspire you to feel that stress in such a situation is wrong. Convincing arguments are given, authoritative opinions are heard. Stress is ugly. This is a sign of weakness. This is disrespect to others.
Parents often raise their daughters as "good girls." They are disturbed by fear, anger and other uncomfortable emotions of the child. Smile and wave. Their feelings are more important than children's ones.
In addition, the expression of uncomfortable emotions in our culture is regarded as weakness.
You are a smart, strong woman, and when an uncouth passerby on the street shouts ‚ÄúCool boobs!‚Äù, You force yourself to ignore rudeness. He is not a maniac, but just a nerd, there is no reason to be angry with him or afraid. It is not worth your attention, nonsense.
However, the brain says, ‚ÄúNightmare!‚Äù And makes you speed up your pace.
<...>
3. The third reason for getting stuck is safer. Is there a strategy that simultaneously saves you from street harassment and relieves the stress caused by it? Sure. Turn around and slap this boor in the face. But then what? Does he suddenly realize the vileness of his harassment and stop them forever? Unlikely. Most likely, the situation will become tense, and he will give you back, and in this case your situation will become even more dangerous. Sometimes a victory is to pass by. With a smile, without retaliatory aggression, saying to yourself that this is nonsense - this is your survival strategy in this case. Use it with dignity. Just remember that such survival strategies do not yet discharge your stress. They only put off this need of the body. This is not a substitute for completing a loop.
So there is a sea of ways to deny, ignore and suppress your stress response! And as a result, we walk, loaded with decades of unfinished cycles. They languish inside our body in anticipation of discharge.



Emily Nagoski, Ph.D. in healthy behavior and an expert on sexuality, and her sister Amelia Nagoski, co-authored the book Burnout. A new approach to stress management. ‚Äù In it, they scientifically explain what stress is and what kind of reaction the body considers normal to it. The sisters also tell why it is dangerous to ignore it, how society affects our well-being and how to get rid of feelings of depression and emotional exhaustion.
